Dr. Skornia
November 17, 1959

1 do not mean to imply that the NA£B should provide consultation only for
the institution seeking to get a hundred-thousand dollars from the gov¬
ernment or some foundation. I believe that the small FM station which
wants to duplicate the Kager study or wants to pretest some of its programs
with audience response profiles should also have help from the NAEB.
The possible reorganization of the committee depends completely on whether
we want to attempt what I have suggested above. If we do attempt it, I
believe that thought should be given to a representation on the committee
of the various research approaches. Dick Evans is obviously a good man
who approaches problems from the social psychologist1a point of view.
Bruce Westley is a good general experimental design and philosophy of
science man. Ken Harwood is good on the historical and broadcast end* X
think that we have noone now who represents the sociology approach or the
educational-psychology approach. For the former, 1 would think that some¬
one such as David Sills, currently acting director of the Bureau of Applied
Social Research at Columbia would be excellent. Howard Rowland at Pitts¬
burgh would represent this point of view also, but not as well. Charles
Neidt of the University of Nebraska would be a very fine educational
psychologist. Hideya Kuraata would be another good sociologist but I just
do not think that he has the time to be of much help.
The problem with this committee that I have suggested should be immediately
obvious. None of them are members of the NAEB except Harwood and, defining
membership loosely, Bruce Westley. It might be possible to have a committee
of NAEB members and include the sort of persons I have named above on the
consulting team. The problem here is that members of the committee would
feel that they should be doing the consulting and, in many cases at least,
I am sure that they should not. This could create great problems. This
is not to say that persons such as Ellery and Merrill are not able and
have not been good members of the committee. However, if you are trying
to obtain funds to set up such a program, their names are not going to
help as much as names such as Sills, Evans, and Neidt. Secondly, and to
be honest, they do not have the research background or experience to give
as much help as I believe the people could whom 1 have nam«&• On the other
hand (and here you see how ambivalent I am), they have been extremely
cooperative as members of the committee this year. Both are quite eager
to work for the NAEB.
Anyway, if such a consulting team was set up, the members (or member) who
would act as consultants on any particular job would depend on the type of
job it was. Obviously, if it is instructional television, an educational
psychologist is needed. If it is general evaluation of a broadcasting
